question_text: Using the definitions provided in the paper, explain the criteria for classifying solid fuels as thermally-thin versus thermally-thick during opposed flame spread, and derive the expression for the thermal penetration depth τ_h. Discuss how this classification affects the thickness of the control volume (L_sy) that considers in-depth conductive heat loss.
standard_answer: According to the paper, the classification between thermally-thin and thermally-thick materials is determined by comparing the actual material thickness τ with the thermal penetration depth τ_h. The paper explicitly states: 'When τ ≤ τ_h, the solid fuel is considered as thermally-thin, while when τ > τ_h it is thermally-thick.' The thermal penetration depth τ_h is defined as τ_h = √(α_s t_s,res), where α_s is the solid thermal diffusivity and t_s,res is the solid residence time. This expression derives from the fundamental heat conduction equation in solids, where the characteristic thermal diffusion length scales with the square root of the product of thermal diffusivity and time. For the control volume thickness that considers in-depth conductive heat loss, the paper specifies L_sy = min[τ, τ_h] = min[τ, √(α_s t_s,res)]. This means that for thermally-thin materials (τ ≤ τ_h), the entire material thickness τ participates in the heat transfer process, so L_sy = τ. For thermally-thick materials (τ > τ_h), heat conduction only penetrates to depth τ_h, so L_sy = τ_h. This distinction is crucial because it determines how much of the solid material actively participates in the heat transfer process during flame spread, affecting the energy balance and ultimately the flame spread behavior.
